newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: PRESS DIGEST - CZECH REPUBLIC - FEB 13.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - CZECH REPUBLIC - FEB 13.

text.p: HOSPODARSKE NOVINY - A second round of discussions on the Czech-German Declaration was held yesterday in parliament. The coalition unanimously supports the declaration, while the Social Democrats are wavering and the communists KSCM and Republicans SPRRSC reject the declaration. The Social Democrats are preparing an accompanying document to the delaration.

- Many farmers are preparing to significantly increase prices of agricultural products. The Agriculture Ministry warns that holding back produce and waiting for better prices will increase output expenses, reduce quality and open the domestic market for more foreign products.

- SPT Telecom will begin offering internet access through modems as of March 31. The monthly charge will most probably be 600 crowns. PRAVO - A spokeswoman for the Finance Ministry, Ludmila Nutilova, announced that American investment bank Salomon Brothers has been chosen to arrange the partial sale of Investicni a Postovni Banka.

- The Regional Development Ministry proposes to increase rent by 71 percent from July 1 this yesr. In 1998, Schneider estimates an increase in rent by 55 percent, in 1999 by 45 percent and in 2000 by 34 percent. LIDOVE NOVINY - The cabinet approved a proposal yesterday for reducing wages of judges and politicians by 10 percent. MLADA FRONTA DNES - The five-day railway strike proved to the management of Czech Railways that two thousand unprofitable trains can be replaced by cheaper buses without too much difficuly. Czech Railways plans to discontinue about one third of its train connections, which will cause many railway workers to lose their jobs.

- The management of General Faculty Hospital, which is facing a legal suit and financial collapse, practically fell apart yesterday when the director, Dana Kocourkova, resigned from her position. Deputy Martin Holcat also left his post.
